While many systems are legacy systems, it's important to note that several of them have not been updated due to their superior reliability compared to their modern counterparts, or the cost of these upgrades (not just in terms of money, but also downtime) would far outweigh the benefits (a vulnerability of the outdated system may have been highly unlikely to be exploited prior to the upgrade).While we need to be resilient against threats, any plan you have must align with the organization's objectives.

Speaking from the manufacturing side, the biggest problems arise from the PLCs and CNC machines that cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. There is no reasonable way to update or replace those gigantic machines without the company going under, so you build security around them instead.
Wait till you find out all that same critical infra is also vulnerable to high explosives we know many hostile states possess!

There are ways to mitigate security risks such as out of date OS's. The big thing about cybersecurity is that there is this ideal, then there is reality, a system being "out of date" or even the software already passing "end of life" doesn't mean that the battle is lost. The reality is some systems simply can't be updated, or updated very easily, and that is ok if we can put in other mitigating factors. Take an MRI machine, so what if its running on windows XP, the cost to buy a new MRI that is using more modern software might simply be not possible (they aren't cheap), so you will deploy other security tools and features to help mitigate that risk.

How is the fact that government, banking, healthcare and other critical infrastructures are still run operating systems and programs that have reached EOL not a catastrophic, epic, infinitely urgent and dire problem?It is absolutely an urgent and dire problem.Because government, banking, healthcare represent the unholy trinity of IT buffoonery and those places either are:1, run by morons (especially gov't)2, conflate compliance for security (especially banks and hospitals)3, haven't learned how to operate using security as a business enabler...... or a combination of the above.Compounding the problem is that security as an industry has a shortage of:1, people who actually have security-related skills2, people who know how to run a business.

still run operating systems and programsYou'd be surprised.I've seen test equipment still running Windows CE, ATMS and other types of kiosks still running Windows XP, there's still a ton of RHEL 5 and 6 on the backend globally, and a lot of telnet still exists in the wild -- especially in industrial applications.... and I don't see a forecast for the apocalypse within the next 24 hours.While it would be nice if we could get folks off of that old tech, the reality is there are still a lot of valid business reasons for why it exsits.With that said, what security professionals should do is not ask why, shame, or look for fucking incompetent governments to make even more laws that it cannot enforce (go read CRA, DORA, and NIS-2 sometime) but rather the security professional should look at how one can harden that existing tech to make it is secure as possible until the tech debt can be paid off.

The answer to your question is the subject of an SEC lawsuit against Solarwinds at the moment. Solarwinds stated to customers and shareholders that they had certain security processes in place, but it appears that this was not the case. At this point, reliable determination of the root cause of initial entry will probably never be known but several solid theories will come out of it.

You haven't found anything because even Solarwind doesn't know for sure how they were initially breach. There was 14 months btw initial breach and their incident response. Most companies keep security logs up to a year. At this point, only the APT team knows how they got in. But considering how poor their security was, it was probably run of the mill phishing credentials harvest campaign and I doubt they had MFA everywhere.

The CEO stated they likely gained access through a compromised O365 account. From there they gained access to specific accounts that granted them access to the dev environment.https://www.crn.com/news/security/solarwinds-ceo-confirms-office-365-email-compromise-played-role-in-broad-based-attack#:~:text=SolarWinds%20CEO%20Sudhakar%20Ramakrishna%20has,in%20business%20and%20technical%20roles.

It's been a minute but IIRC, Solarwinds claimed on Twitter that an intern's Solarwinds github access was compromised due to a reused password. The APT actors leveraged that into access to the upcoming build commits which were later digitally signed and deployed as the next update. They had already been watching internal Solarwinds CI/CD workflows long enough to know potential targets, repo locations, update and deployment schedules, and on what cadence final commits were to be digitally signed. From a tradecraft perspective, it was truly swoon worthy. Wait until you research how they tracked their compromised victims (custom encoded domain generation algorithm subdomains). And they were so patient...literally one or two actions on objective and then wait two months before the next actions on objective.Because "blame the intern" was so poorly received, especially in light of FireEye's "take full responsibility" approach when they made their announcement they'd been compromised, Solarwinds quietly removed this claim.I will say one thing having worked with some highly sophisticated red teams/pentesters, it's not uncommon to find useful logins, secret tokens, and API keys buried in git archives because the repo owner didn't properly scrub old code.
State sponsored intelligence gathering operations are still classified. We might only know 10% of the story.

I spend most of my time talking to boards and their committees.CISOs in my business report into me but I am effectively a CISO in all but title.I skimmed the article and TBH I‚Äôm not completely aligned.I would be pretty annoyed if someone labelled me, my team, my peers as soothsayers.Security is an operational risk, like many others. It benefits from being integrated into enterprise risk frameworks and having documented, repeatable and transparent process for identifying and assessing risk in the context of the framework.Unlike other areas of operational risk, such as finance, boards tend to have less experience of InfoSec. They do (usually) have good understanding of risk management principles. As with many of the other teams we interact with, we have to speak their language and make it easy for them to make decisions. Quantifying risk from a financial perspective, and articulating in terms of risk appetite etc. is the most successful way of approaching it, in my experience.

There's a reason why a lot of technically-minded people don't make great executives. To convince the higher-up staff, you have to use their language: dollars and risk. They don't care about Lockbit, they care about how much money they lose when Lockbits messes their stuff up, and the hit to their reputation.People hate building KPIs and measuring performance, but this is what it's for. Translating your work into $$$ so that the CFO who doesn't understand why it takes more than 1 person to monitor alerts for a Fortune 50 company can see the effect you have when Lockbit hits every other org but yours.
